subsection_content:
If appendicitis is not treated promptly, it can lead to serious complications as follows:
Rupture of the appendix: A ruptured appendix will spread infection throughout the abdomen, leading to peritonitis, which is life-threatening. This condition requires immediate surgery to remove the damaged area and clean the abdominal cavity.; Rupture of the appendix: A ruptured appendix will spread infection throughout the abdomen, leading to peritonitis, which is life-threatening. This condition requires immediate surgery to remove the damaged area and clean the abdominal cavity.
Abscess: This is a condition where a pocket of pus forms in the abdomen. In most cases, the doctor will drain the abscess by placing a tube through the abdominal wall into the affected area. The tube is left in place for about two weeks and the patient is also given a combination of antibiotics to eliminate the infection. Surgical excision will then be indicated.; Abscess: This is a condition where a pocket of pus forms in the abdomen.
